title: 108_hr898
content: The Act may be cited as the "Lumbee Recognition Act". The Act of June 7, 1956 is amended to acknowledge the Lumbee Indians of North Carolina as descendants of coastal tribes and a distinct Indian community. North Carolina has recognized them as a tribe since 1885, and in 1956, the US Congress acknowledged them as well, but withheld certain benefits. The Lumbee Indians were acknowledged as an Indian tribe by the US Congress in 1956, but were denied certain benefits. Congress now recognizes the Lumbee Tribe and grants them full federal recognition and associated privileges. The Lumbee Tribe is granted full federal recognition and associated privileges by Congress. The Act of June 7, 1956 is amended to grant federal recognition to the Lumbee Tribe of North Carolina, extending all laws and regulations of general application to Indians and Indian tribes to the tribe and its members. Additionally, any group of Indians in Robeson and adjoining counties, North Carolina, not enrolled in the Lumbee Tribe may petition for tribal acknowledgement. The Lumbee Tribe and its members are eligible for all services and benefits provided to Indians. The Lumbee Tribe of North Carolina and its members are eligible for federal recognition, services, and benefits provided to Indians. Members residing in specific counties are considered to be on or near an Indian reservation. The Secretary of the Interior will verify a tribal roll and develop a budget for services in consultation with the tribe. The Secretary of Health and Human Services, in consultation with the Lumbee Tribe of North Carolina, will determine the needs and budget for services eligible to tribe members. The tribal roll, verified by the Secretary of the Interior, will define the service population for federal service delivery. Verification must comply with the tribe's constitution adopted in 2000 and be completed within one year of the enactment of this section. The Lumbee Tribe of North Carolina's membership criteria, as outlined in their constitution adopted in 2000, must be verified within one year of the enactment of this section. Fee lands to be conveyed to the United States for trust purposes will be treated as on-reservation acquisitions if located in Robeson County. The State of North Carolina will have jurisdiction over criminal offenses and civil actions on lands owned by or held in trust for the Lumbee Tribe. The Lumbee Tribe of North Carolina's membership criteria must be verified within one year. The State of North Carolina will have jurisdiction over criminal offenses and civil actions on lands owned by or held in trust for the Lumbee Tribe. The Secretary of the Interior is authorized to accept transfers of jurisdiction from the State of North Carolina to the United States. The provisions of this subsection shall not affect the application of section 109 of the Indian Child Welfare Act of 1978. Authorized appropriations for carrying out this Act.
